Comment: I love this little monitor for the price. Perfect for using as an extended desktop for a laptop with an HDMI cable. Great picture quality and the ability to tweak the blue light for nighttime usage. The one thing I cannot figure out how to fix, that costs it 5 stars is that when the current input (HDMI 1) which is plugged into the laptop goes on sleep mode, the input automatically shifts to input 2 (HDMI with a Firestick). The process to switch it back is relatively simple but requires multiple button pushes on the back of the screen and if input 1 is not active immediately will switch right back to input 2. A remote would have made this process a lot easier, but this does not support one.  Same goes with volume.  Overall I am glad I purchased it, but not as good as it could have been.

Comment: I've owned a Sceptre 4K 55'' TV for about 4 years and I'm happy with it. So when I needed a monitor it was one of the brands I looked at. I bought this a couple of months ago and never regretted it. I use it on my desktop, so 1080p was fine for me. Being a smaller screen than the 55 inch, to me it looks just as good. Adding in the price, you can't beat it. It was a easy setup, with the controls on the bottom right. The stand was a snap to install. The only downside to this. is the speakers. Their mounted in the back and throw the sound out that way. They could of at least had them throw the sound downward onto the top of the desk. I tried a test using some paper clip boxes taped to back of the monitor and it worked! Still like all build-in TV or monitor speakers,  they aren't great sounding. Your better off with some 2.1 sound system. Considering the picture quality, easy setup and price this is worthy buy for anyone.

Comment: A quick word of advice to everyone who buys this monitor:  when you first hook it up to your computer, you will find that the screen (esp text, when scrolling) gets quite blurry and the colors might seem blotchy.  I was thinking that the monitor was defective when I saw it, but, after some homework, figured out that the problem is caused by faulty "overdrive" feature (or maybe not faulty?  never actually saw this feature before).  The control for "Overdrive" is under "System" and it's set to "medium" by default.  Turn it off.  Then the problem of blurry screen will go away and after that, the monitor is great.  (While I can't speak to the durability of this particular product, I've had generally excellent experience with Scepter monitors, all of which (I've had 4, including this one) were very durable over 3-4 years that I've used them.  At minimum, they products are worth it, IMHO.

Comment: I ordered this monitor because my old 30in cheapo tv finally took a crap, so I bought this and made it my main display making my LG Flatron W2246 my secondary display. It's not a terrible monitor for what you paid for. In some ways it's better than the LG in some ways, brighter whites and slightly more saturated darks. One issue I have with it is that I can't get the 75Hz refresh rate that is on the box and in the manual. Another issue I have is that it's not as crisp as the LG, when watching videos the image is slightly more crisp and cooler as far as color. Overall this monitor is a great beginner monitor if you buy it at the $90 that I did, just make sure that if you are running a dual monitor setup that you have a stand that let's you adjust the height of the monitors individually because the VESA mount is low on the monitor and that most likely will put it at a higher viewing angle than your other monitor... trust me I know.

Comment: I so love this monitor and its performance that,  since 2018, I have purchased 7 of these monitors.  4 were for a home office in NJ and 2 were for a home office in FL for vacations.  I gave away the 4 in NJ, prior to moving to FL.  Thinking that I still had 4 in FL, I gave 1 of those to my brother for his security system.  Upon arrival, I realized I only originally had 2 in FL and now I was left with 1.  I struggled with 1 monitor for 4 months.  I wouldn't purchase another because the pandemic supply and demand had pushed prices too high for my retirement income and I wanted the monitors to match.  I happen to see this one at a discount which brought it into my budget range so I jumped on it.  It isn't much more than my 2018 purchases however, the last few I bought for FL all have built-in speakers and 2 HDMI ports.  Whaaaat? Comment: Okay, the panel itself is excellent, bright, sharp, and easy to read. That covers the good stuff, and if that was all, I would be giving this a 5-star review. However, I purchased this specifically to VESA mount it to a desk-mounted arm. As a VESA mountable monitor, it sucks. The mounting for the included stand completely blocks the VESA mount. I had to literally cut the stand mount off of the monitor to fit the VESA mounting plate onto the monitor. If you want to use a wall or arm mount for your monitor, DO NOT get this monitor. Whatever engineer approved the position and use of this stand mount did a horrible job. Again, this monitor is unsuitable for VESA mount unless you are willing to physically modify (i.e., cut the damn mount off with a hacksaw, thus eliminating your warranty) the monitor before use.

Comment: If you are rating this like you ordered a $500 top of the line gaming monitor, then it's YOU that has issues, not the product. For under $120 this monitor well surpassed my expectations initially, as for longevity, we'll see. Great picture quality, thin appearance, and pretty small bezels. Came with HDMI cord (wasn't expecting that) and spacers for wall mounts/other mounting kits. Usable UI for adjustments if that's your thing. I honestly just set it up, plugged it in and bobs you're uncle. Again, it was only $104 when I ordered it, so this review is based on that. What else can be said? 24 inches is 24 inches, 75 hertz is 75 hertz, colors are colored and cords do cord things! For the price, it's definitely recommended and expectations where exceeded. Don't buy a monitor under $120 and try to review it like a $500 god-like gaming accessory.

Comment: These monitors started out great.  We have scads of other Sceptre monitors at our office.  All the other ones are well past two years old and doing just fine.  This set was a matching set of E248W units and were unlike our other purchases.  I have removed them from service at 14 months because they both started getting lines in them.  At first it was a just a few and out of any real area of concern, but again this was just outside the warranty period.  I cannot possibly be the only person who has had this happen.  Both failed the exact same way, with multiple colored lines on the top and bottom - increasing in number and severity over time.  I have since replaced them and Sceptre support states they're out of warranty.  They did cost less than $100 when purchased and that should have been a red flag to me.  You get what you pay for.

Comment: Very nice monitor.  You can't ask for too much considering the price.  My only caveat is that the monitor ALWAYS auto-detects the active input.  In one HDMI, I have my PC running, and through the other HDMI, I have my game console running.  If my game console needs to reboot after updating, or the signal flinches for whatever other reason, the display automatically switches to the other HDMI input if it's currently active.  What if I don't want that?  It's not too much of a hassle, but I'm reminded of it every time it happens.  Other than that, I highly recommend.
Normalized_Comment: nice monitor cant ask much considering price caveat monitor always autodetects active input one hdmi pc running hdmi game console running game console need reboot updating signal flinch whatever reason display automatically switch hdmi input currently active dont want much hassle im reminded every time happens highly recommend

Comment: I got this on a good price on here, as it filled a couple specific needs I had. I'm using this on a boat running navigation  software on a Raspberry Pi 4. For that purpose, it should work well. Screen has good clarity and does get rather bright when set. Including standoffs for vesa mounts to clear the stand mount is a nice addition. The speakers are a joke for anything but a very quiet home-desk where you're sitting less than 5' from it. They aren't very full sounding, and even at max volume they get drowned out by any background noise. Luckily having an audio out jack helps with this. The only other thing I would've liked to see though would be a remote to adjust the settings instead of having to reach around to the back. Until you have a feel for them, or keep the manual handy, you have to fumble a little to get through the menu. Even just a basic menu-up-down-enter remote would've been good.

Comment: The picture quality is decent: the darkness level is not so great, the color “black” is more of a gray-ish tone. Brightness level can be adjusted, you can also adjust the colors, but both have limited range. Speakers are poor quality, it reminds me of a retro speaker that my grandpa would play his radio broadcasts, but for the price you pay, you’re getting quite a lot. Especially if you purchase this when it goes on sale. You do get 1080p with 75hz and that’s really more than what you need for an average, “work-at-home” purposes monitor, or for a second monitor screen. If you’re looking for a gaming monitor, you’re on the wrong page. Again, this is definitely not for gaming purposes, but solid enough for work purposes, at home, second monitor, school, documents, and playing few YT videos (not cinema quality) etc.

Comment: I am a writer and I have always used just one computer for all my needs.  However, I decided to add a monitor to write my books on, then do research on the original computer.  This works great for me and this is a great monitor.  Some reviews question the difficulty in using a second monitor.  I can only offer limited experience because I don't do a lot of things with i, only write bookst.  First, it is easy to set up this monitor with the HDMI cable they include.  You simply hook the USB type connections on both ends of the cable to the computer monitor and then to this monitor.  You are ready to go.  I use MS Word to write my books.  To move a book from the original computer to the second computer monitor, I right click on the large blue strip at the top of the Word document, hold it firmly and drag it to this monitor.  Easy to do!  The second monitor has a task bar at the bottom and tool bar at the top to use without being forced to use the computer screen.  This is just like everything in the electronic world, you have to "intuitively" learn to manipulate this second  to suit your needs.  Hope this helps someone!

Comment: I was looking for a cheap monitor upgrade.  I looked for days really hesitant to order because of bad reviews, mainly because of defective products.  I gave in and decided to purchase this 24 inch, 75hrz monitor.  I am glad I did.  This monitor was a huge upgrade.  My old monitor was 21.5 inches with 60 hrz refresh rate.  I notice a huge difference already.  The movement of the mouse alone is way smoother and doesn't lag when moving it around.  The picture is crystal clear, and very sharp quality.  Forgot to mention this but my old monitor didn't have an HDMI port.  This monitor has 2 HDMI ports as well as a VGA port.  There are also built in speakers but I don't use them.  I usually use a headset so the quality of the speakers didn't alter my review of this gem.  Of course, I had to adjust the picture brightness, contrast and gamma to fit my liking, which I do for every monitor I get.  As of now, it works perfectly fine and I love it.  It is safe to say this is the best monitor I have used thus far.  Incredibly cheap, packed with features and runs great!

Comment: This monitor is very poor quality, even for the low cost. It lasted only 1 week past 3 months and this morning when we turned it on, the screen is completely white. Sceptre claims this has a 1 year warranty, but if you can’t get in contact with them, then obviously there’s no way to process a claim. Comment: With  COVID we were all sent home and I was blessed to work from home. I  work in mortgages so one monitor just would not cut it . Menu is really easy to navigate , speakers are great but I have a Surround Sound Bar so I will not really use that. I use my Alexa app to turn them on and off , but due to the side of the plug , I have to apply 2 separate interfaces. up to 75Hz does not get hot and totally worth the price. Comment: This is the 3rd or 4th Sceptre monitor/TV I have owned. They have all been great products. This 24" monitor replaced an old Westinghouse monitor that had a bad switch (turned off by itself, and troubleshooting didn't fix it). The new Sceptre screen has given me a 3rd monitor (laptop lid + 2 externals) for use on my work laptop, which felt cramped at 2 screens and nearly impossible to use w/1 screen. The new Sceptre model has several video presets, so I can get close to matching my other displays. I have not connected it to my personal computer for gaming, so I cannot comment on how the 75hz refresh rate is for the Steam games I play. But, for my DevOps work tasks (AWS, Jenkins, Instana, Splunk, Sonatype, etc.), it has been a welcome addition to my workstation. 2 big thumbs-up.

Comment: My far more expensive Dell monitor suddenly bit the dust out of nowhere and I didn't have a protection plan (lesson learned). I ordered this because this was about as much as I could afford without going really tiny or lower than 1080p. Once I figured out how to work the menu controls and adjusted the picture to my preferences, it's definitely a good monitor for the price. At first it felt washed out compared to my Dell monitor, but that one had a shiny screen as compared to this one's matte screen, and was also a $300 monitor that I got open box, so of course the picture quality was better. Once I got used to it, it looks totally fine and I don't have refresh rate problems (though I don't play any heavily frame-reliant games, mostly just Dead by Daylight and simple indie games). The mounting system was different than what the instructions showed, but I figured it out. It is a little wobbly but I don't see why that's a problem if you're not moving it around constantly; it stays stable enough for me.

Comment: For everyone who wants to know, no this is not a full out gaming monitor. No it is not a tv, although technically you could use it like one. But I will say it works pretty good for the money. The picture is smooth and the resolution is pretty nice for a $100 monitor. But this isn't going to be anything like a 4K 144hz monitor. It gets the job done and it's nice for casual gaming. And I'm plugged into an Asus gaming laptop for these results, so it is running off of a Nvidia GeForce GTX 1050. Also my monitor did come with an HDMI cable in the box, so that was a nice addition. It also comes with the hardware for a wall mount. My only complaint is that out of the box the picture was super washed out. With some adjustments I got it back to normal, but it is worth noting that you may have to make some adjustments

Comment: These are razor-thin, and though they do have a bezel, it's modest. I haven't "performance-tested" these to any strenuous extent, but they've performed exceptionally-well for both office work and casual gaming (ark/minecraft/satisfactory). Especially-nice is the wall-wart DC power supply - I've always had heavier 3prong power cables going to monitors, and on a 3x stand they can be rather bulky and tough to hide - these, instead, are very thin wires for power, which were very easy to hide. Hypothetically, if the wall-wart ever fails, it ought to be easy to replace, rather than chucking the screen for a bad supply.

Comment: These monitors a what I would call good.  They do the job, have a good image quality and simple controls.  They are not high end devices, but they will get the job done and the price point is very attractive too.  One of the 4 I bought had some weird image quality issues that came and went only once, never again since that one day.  The controls are simple and easy to use, pretty standard stuff.  The connectivity is good with HDMI and VGA, DVI seems to be a thing of the past.  DP would be nice but not required in my setup.  Overall these monitors are a good value and meet my needs for a good price.  The only complaint I have is the sound quality.  If you need to use the onboard speakers be prepared that they will sound very “tiny” and have absolutely no bass to them at all.  They work in a pinch if you have nothing else but you will definitely want an external speaker set.

Comment: Running this monitor for the last two weeks off my GTX 660, and it was a great purchase. For $100 you get a very flexible monitor that passes most of my baseline tests. No dead pixels on arrival, none of the spotting other people have had. Initially plugging it in, pixels were very white. Be sure to set up your graphics card for 75hz, and then I further adjusted contrast and brightness until colors felt correct and the whiteness went away. I run it with low brightness and higher than normal contrast, and adjust the back-light level to compensate. Considering this monitor is over half as cheap as other similar monitors on the market, its a great buy.

Comment: i bought this about 4-5 months ago and i had it as a main monitor for a while until i bought my new monitor. as a main monitor, it was terrible. it has an issue of going black every so often for a few seconds after a month. i assumed it was my graphics card. i put another monitor on the HDMI slot this one was on and moved this one over, issue still happened on this monitor while the other monitor on the slot this was in didn't have that affect. if you are looking for a second display that is above 60hz and are not really going to look at this monitor at all, i would then recommend it. but if you are planning on using this for a main display or a display you will be looking at for a while, this ain't it chief. i would recommend paying a little more if you want something over 60hz, cause this definitely will be more trouble than it is worth. i did have an issue of it not being 60hz but i found out a few weeks ago that it is user error, not the monitor. i have tried changing HDMI ports on the monitor as well thinking one of the ports was bad and that didn't fix the issue. i tried the VGA slot, that didn't fix the issue. the only thing i really enjoyed about this monitor was the colors were really good and was very vibrant but besides that i don't have anything else good to say about it. speakers sounded terrible but i can't fault them on that because of the price. there are better monitors out there for a little more, go check them out instead

Comment: After taking the time to set up a home office I went to plug these monitors in, excited that it was the last step. After plugging them in they said they would not detect an input and immediately went into sleep mode. I thought maybe it was an issue with my computer or USBC hub. Spent a few hours trying to figure out if it was a software, driver, windows or computer problem. Couldn't find any solution. Then drove to Best Buy to but a new cable and hub at $150. Plugged the new hub in, same issue. At this point I began to suspect the monitors but how could 2 be bad?! Plugged computer into my TV and it immediately extended the desktop. At this point I went back and checked out the monitors. I was using the supplied HDMI cables. There is a plastic bezel around each input that extends out about 1/8 inch. The plastic around the HDMI input pushes up against the plastic bezle and makes it so that the HDMI cable is not fully inserted into the monitor. I pushed it in hard and the monitor turned on. I then had to literally break and Dremel around the HDMI plug in the monitor to create clearance for the plug. This level of stupidity by the manufacturer is incredible.  I would like 4 hours of my life back please. 🤦‍♂️

Comment: I ordered this product on 6.16.20 and received it shortly after.  The outer packaging advertises the item inside and is held closed with clear shipping tape.  The outer packaging had normal wear and tear, meaning scuffs and small edge peels, but nothing that would infer that the inside product could be damaged.  Once opened the product is tightly packaged in a Styrofoam shell with a static cling screen protector.  It comes with screws to mount on the stand, mount on a wall mount and even a magnetized Phillips screwdriver (that was a major plus for me bc I can always use a new screwdriver) as well as an HDMI cable and power adapter.  The size of the 24" monitor is very nice, with barely 1/2 inch trim around the screen.  I work from home using a laptop, so I was very excited to work with the monitor but when I plugged it into the power strip...nothing.  I plugged into the wall...nothing.  I plugged it into another outlet on a different wall...nothing.  I took it to the bathroom and plugged it in...nothing.  Kitchen - nothing. Living room - nothing.  I contacted their customer service via email that very night.  They replied within 24 hours, asking me to register the item and provide them with the model and serial number.  Due to the 1 year warranty they mailed me a new power adapter free of charge.  It should be here within a week.  I will update my review when I see if that was the problem or not. Fingers crossed that is all it is!
Normalized_Comment: ordered product received shortly outer packaging advertises item inside held closed clear shipping tape outer packaging normal wear tear meaning scuff small edge peel nothing would infer inside product could damaged opened product tightly packaged styrofoam shell static cling screen protector come screw mount stand mount wall mount even magnetized phillips screwdriver major plus bc always use new screwdriver well hdmi cable power adapter size monitor nice barely inch trim around screen work home using laptop excited work monitor plugged power stripnothing plugged wallnothing plugged another outlet different wallnothing took bathroom plugged innothing kitchen nothing living room nothing contacted customer service via email night replied within hour asking register item provide model serial number due year warranty mailed new power adapter free charge within week update review see problem finger crossed

Seems to work normally when not in fullscreen viewing. The worst part about the monitor is the viewing angle. Unless you are looking directly in the center and it is set perfectly to eye level it is unusable. Even turning your head to look at the edges shifts the colors and brightness. Overall it is way overpriced for what you get. Might be ok for basic productivity but not good for gaming or media consumption.

Comment: I know what you're thinking, "two duds in a row probably means the problem is between the keyboard and the chair" but hear me out. We got this monitor for the good reviews. Straight away, the flickering started for the PC. We tried a different source (a PS4) and the flickering continued. We figured it's either the HDMI cable or the monitor, so we tried a different cable and still the flickering persisted. Most likely it's a defective monitor, so we returned it and here we are with another flickering monitor. We tried the same troubleshooting techniques... We also tried messing with the monitor's settings so see if there's some config causing it, but it's still an issue. So we returned it for a refund. Risk it if you want, the returns were easy, but I'd advise going with something else if you want to save time.

Comment: The offer was too good to be true. I needed a monitor that worked for my magic mirror build and I found this one. When it shipped, I was ecstatic. The deal I found for a 75 Hz monitor was amazing. I go to fire it up just to learn it had an internal crack that messed up half to three-fourths of the screen. I try to send it back but it was past Amazon's 30-day refund. I contact the supplier, Spectre, to get a warranty to send it back, and they tell me they do not deal with "External" damage when it was an "Internal" crack in the hardware they sent me. If you are looking for a quality monitor that you can expect to work after being shipped to you, I do NOT recommend this monitor, nor this brand as their customer service in atrociously awful and hardware is cheaply made.

Comment: As a monitor itself, it's great. Good refresh rate, picture isn't spectacular but it's definitely good enough. I use it for a mix of gaming and multitasking for online classes. Build and materials quality is surprisingly high for the price point. My biggest issues with it are a. the built in speakers and b. the fact that the monitor doesn't ask for the right resolution in a lot of games. The last issue probably won't be an issue if it's your only monitor, but it tries to use my native resolution from my laptop in a lot of games. Not a deal breaker but gets annoying when starting new games for the first time. The first issue is a little more annoying. I have to disable the audio driver for the monitor every time I start up a game, and in Warzone the chat audio will come out of the monitor by default while the game audio comes through my headset. Comment: I've read several reviews from the 5 star ratings on the way down the chain to the 1 star ratings. We have used this monitor over the past 6ish months in our IT department and have NEVER had any of the issues the lower ratings described. Could some of the ratings be because of maybe a bad device? YES. Not every device is 100% flawless. Humans make and assemble the monitors and I don't know a single perfect flawless human so therefore there will never be flawless merchandise. I may suggest that possibly the issues may be the result of handling from delivery to user. And since we get ours shipped usually by FedEx I probably would cautiously lean more to the side of how the monitors were handled by the user. Just my opinion.  These monitors work as expected for our IT department.

Comment: No DVI input to monitor.  So purchased a DIV to HDMI adapter cable because wanted optimum video resolution.  (old PC has only DVI or VGA output ports).  With the Amazon adapter cable OR VGA cable; nearly perfect picture.  Very / very bright.  In fact had to reduce backlight and brightness settings to use in bedroom / office.  Monitor self detects input or can change manually.  OSD has about any setting you could possibly want. With VGA cable used 3.5mm audio input cable.  Works good.  When using the DVI to HDMI adapter cable got a surprise:  As soon as plug in HDMI to monitor; no audio thru internal speakers.  Turns out DVI does not output audio AND standard HDMI supports integrated audio; thus cuts off the 3.5mm audio input.  (no sound with DVI to HDMI cable)  For now reverted back to VGA so speaker audio would work.  Still pic quality is outstanding with 1920 X 1080: 75Hz resolution using either then DVI to HDMI cable or VGA.  Now internal monitor speakers are not boom box quality, but OK to watch an occasion You Tube or other presentation.  Will have to think about it, but might try small Soundbar along with DVI / HDMI cable or just use with VGA as is.  (resolution is same)  OBTW .. Comment: I bought this as a budget option to replace an aging 19" Dell monitor that was starting to discolor and ghost, and I couldn't be happier! It's not an IPS panel, but it makes up for that with brightness and response time. The built-in speakers are a bit tinny, but they're more than acceptable if you're on a budget and not a major audiophile. I've spend upward of 400 hours gaming and doing light CAD work on this monitor with no noticeable eye strain. If you're on a budget, I would whole heartedly recommend this and other Spectre monitors as a worthwhile alternative!

Comment: Great product, the visuals are amazing. I use this monitor for gaming and it runs smoother than my tv. What sets this monitor aside from most monitors is that it has an input audio and output audio source which is pretty awesome because I can just plug my headphones into the monitor and hear everything clearly. The audio on its own is not the greatest without headphones as I’m used to the surround sound system on my tv, however if you put headphones into the monitor, the sound is perfect. In terms of the audio without headphones, I had difficulty trying to distinguish where enemies were during games based on their footsteps, however when I put headphones in, I was able to properly distinguish where people were. So I’m conclusion, it’s an amazing product and definitely worth your money, but if you’re gonna use it for gaming, make sure you have headphones or another audio input !!
